div.p: Greetings. More than enough, my dearest brother Tobias, I am tormented by the complaints of the brothers, even though yours has not been added, nor was there any need for an excuse with me, nor will I pass it on to those who, what they accuse you of, also accuse us. With patience and constancy, we have prevailed so far; you too will prevail, sufficiently secure and confirmed in your innocence. So let these things be. I am sending back to you your poem about the Sculensian prodigy; I cannot do otherwise now. I have added a letter from our MÃ¼ller, which I ask you to return to me. I do not ask, lest you be offended in this matter; for you know that I have done what I could, and what happened, happened beyond our hope and expectation; I would have preferred it to be published. Furthermore, what I have received from elsewhere, I have inserted into this smeared paper. I thank you for the continued history of the Rhaetian judgment and for the letters of our Lentulus. Today it is written from Bern that a meeting is being held in Gaius (to Gee) with the Savoyard prince; the Bernese have sent both consuls and quaestors there. Someone came from France, who reported that the king, in various places (for he frequently changes location), is convening a meeting of the estates, to which he himself will come with 4000 horsemen, by which name few will come to that assembly; the nobles in France again have their preachers; Monbrun is still in arms; the Huguenots have newly appointed leaders and standard-bearers, so that if any force arises, they are ready for defense. I do not think now, as before, that anything else will happen than that Ganthner will cause you trouble; but he can do enough, so that one deals with him seriously and gets rid of him. For I know the deceitful, unstable, and depraved nature of these sectarians. May the Lord convert or restrain him!
Greet the honorable consuls, fellow minister Campell, Victor, and also other lords and friends, Pontisellas, Bonet, Gregory, and finally each and every one. Farewell.
To the well-learned, pious, and faithful lord Tobias Egli, pastor at St. Martin in Chur, my dear lord and brother. Chur.
